author: justjared725
body:
Yeah + $40k of equipment.  But the real story was the correction statement: "Not included in the 2020 Q1 financials are the previously referenced Bitcoin buys of 513 BTC (circa 2014) and the conflicting 576 BTC (circa 2016) as seen and carried over from previous managements reports. As of Q1 2020 current management has yet to receive any company (CCTL) books, statements, bank info, property, assets or proof of any Bitcon holdings from old management. All previous financial reports 2018 and 2019 were mostly reconstructed from previous reports filed by Coin Citadel and old CEO Bill Schaefer. Without substantive proof of current Bitcoin holdings still held by old management, or that a loss was incurred from an unusual event and or negligent action by prior management due to lost access to private keys and or wallets, or Bitcoin was sold and previous sale was never disclosed to new management, Coin Citadel cannot continue to reference the aforementioned Bitcoin Treasury in its financials moving forward."

So it's either been a scam or someone pocketed 500+ bitcoin, or someone lost access to wallets. NO ONE JUST MISPLACES THE KEYS TO $30m OF BITCOIN.

author: TCB47
body:
Vanguard has some very good funds available in the US & I would assume they have something similar in the UK.  My wife & I have our primary investments housed with Fidelity Investment here in the U.S. and they are all in a diversified retirement account.

Current distribution is 40/60 with 40% in bond & 60% stock mutuals.  We are retirement age hence the heavier allocation to bonds.  You could get by with a heavier stock weighting.

Our stocks are split among growth funds, medical, technology and communications.  The keys for us have been to not panic and let things ride during some of the downturns.  I do rebalance the account at the first of the year to try to keep the bond/stock split close to my desired weighting.

With retirement funds, I have stayed away from straight stock ownership and for us, that has worked very well.  It's amazing what the compounding will accomplish by allowing the funds to reinvest the dividends and capital gains back info the funds.  Good luck.

BTW, I am using Robinhood to "play" with options with some disposable, not going to miss it, funds.  I just won't get wild with the retirement account.

author: dont-YOLO-ragequit
body:
This really lack any due Diligence. 
Are you just trolling to get the answers fed to you or did you just poorly formulated a Change my view post? 

Doesn't reay matter who invented it as the basis of it has been optimized by the competition between all crypto currencies. In other words the un verified unsecured currencies died a decade plus ago from not being hack proof.

The currencies are currently competing with each other the same way the Yen, Euro, US dollar and more are competing with each other. They all have their own supply and demand and the more credible companies hop on, the more credible it will get.(compared to currencies being manipulated by stimulus packages, interest rates and buying other currencies). 


It IS being regulated and audited. The mid February crash happened because some firm falsely stated that they found a double transaction. It was later backtracked but the damage was done. 

The values is linked to how hard it is to mine 1 coin at this point. You could mine a coin with an idle computer so at the time it was chump change, now it takes high powered hardware, a heavy electricity bill and a ton of cooling to get one so the price goes along with it + how it can only get harder to have one. 

Your coins are as secure as you make it. There are crypted USB keys  to keep your wallet safe but like everything, the more valuable it is, the more someone will have the patience to get it.

The future is in that it cuts currency exchange fees(the banks) and rates(the government) and financial institutions from host to client. You get a coin, you trade parts of it the way you want internationally or confidentially with no brick and mortar fees. 

The GME saga showed big banks can and will interfere to make money over the well being of free market.

Bitcoin might not be the end all solution but something can be said about the infrastructure behind it where no "package"(hash) can be hacked since the time and date , the number of characters, sender and receivers , and so much of the the data that makes the hash can be used to encrypt it thus can't be "reinserted" in the blockchain.

author: canucksunlimited
body:
Have you considered cold storage? 

Trezor or Ledger are reputable brands and they can be purchased through licensed distributors in Canada if you check their websites to see who is licensed to sell them. With the price of spreads and fees on some of these custodians, the wallets practically pay for themselves. On top of this, you own the asset yourself instead of some third party (which is the whole point of decentralization). Not your keys not your coins kind of thing. 

After you’ve received your wallet and you’ve set it up, you use an exchange to purchase BTC or ETH and then transfer it into your Trezor or Ledger. As others have mentioned Shakepay is a  good exchange for Canadians. 

If you want to sell, you transfer your funds back to shakepay and trade your BTC or ETH for CAD. From there you send the CAD off the exchange and back into your account through e-transfer. Shakepay’s only fees are  1.5% spread on buy and sell.

author: TemporaryUsername-
body:
I would disagree that anonymity was never the goal. Satoshi specifically addressed privacy concerns in a separate section of their white paper.

>The traditional banking model achieves a level of privacy by limiting access to information to the parties involved and the trusted third party. The necessity to announce all transactions publicly precludes this method, but **privacy can still be maintained by breaking the flow of information in another place: by keeping public keys anonymous.** **The public can see that someone is sending an amount to someone else, but without information linking the transaction to anyone.** This is similar to the level of information released by stock exchanges, where the time and size of individual trades, the "tape", is made public, but without telling who the parties were... 

The fact that Satoshi remains anonymous supports the case, I think. It is meant to be transacted in public, but the identify of the parties transacting is meant to be anonymous.

It will be zero hit to their bottom line.  Pure $100m of grade a cheddar cheese with which we can smother some glorious tendies.  And as we munch down on those deep fried birds, consider this:

If you were Pfizer, why would you pay $100m per year for something when you could just buy the whole dang thing and only owe yourself $100m per year?

People think GME was a squeeze but this has heavy short interest, an insider with tons of shares who could quickly use them in diamond hand fashion when big daddy Pfizer comes in to clear a debt off the books of 100m per year through a buyout attempt, and holds the keys to some effective covid services.  And hint hint, covid isn’t going away, it’s the new flu.

Alternatively, let’s say Pfizer buys them out, gives frosty a boatload of Pfizer shares (they pay dividends so he can retire and still earn millions) and pays a handsome sum to all of us retailers for our shares.  Frost has already said he won’t sell unless he rescues those who bought during high offerings which means he would be looking at $18-20 per share price point.  

Either scenario gets investors 300-400% gains.

I do live in fantasy land so not financial advice.

author: tcwtcw
body: With Robinhood you’re not really buying the asset, though. “Not your keys, not your coins” is a popular saying among crypto traders. Robinhood and PayPal are basically selling you a Bitcoin IOU. You buy the price of bitcoin at the time, not the actual coin. They don’t give you an address and you can’t move it off their exchange - a crucial feature of true crypto ownership.

author: canucksunlimited
body:
Have you considered cold storage? 

Trezor or Ledger are reputable brands and they can be purchased through licensed distributors in Canada if you check their websites to see who is licensed to sell them. With the price of spreads and fees on some of these custodians, the wallets practically pay for themselves. On top of this, you own the asset yourself instead of some third party (which is the whole point of decentralization). Not your keys not your coins kind of thing. 

After you’ve received your wallet and you’ve set it up, you use an exchange to purchase BTC or ETH and then transfer it into your Trezor or Ledger. As others have mentioned Shakepay is a  good exchange for Canadians. 

If you want to sell, you transfer your funds back to shakepay and trade your BTC or ETH for CAD. From there you send the CAD off the exchange and back into your account through e-transfer. Shakepay’s only fees are  1.5% spread on buy and sell.

author: JackLocke366
body:
What differentiated coinbase in the beginning is that they didn't present a trading platform for and selling bitcoin. The price was the price. There was no bid/ask, no level 2 data, and no limit orders. You hooked your bank account directly to coinbase and it handled buying and selling for you. The app came way after MT Gox died.

As for apps, iirc there was one before it that allowed buy/sell but also served as a wallet where you got to own your keys but didn't need to have a local copy of the blockchain  (blockchain dot com maybe, it's fuzzy). Practically everyone used the wallet but no one used the buy sell because the fees were too high.

author: InitiaLInvestor
body: Notice on robinhood they don’t allow you to send and receive crypto through them, they are a stock brokerage not a crypto exchange. if they don’t give you your keys, (ie a personal crypto wallet) that’s not your crypto because it’s not physically your possession to do what you will with it. All you can do is buy and sell it meaning you are not buying crypto you are investing in it, It’s an exchange of fiat for an “iou crypto”. For example say you bought 100 goldfish for $100 but the person you bought them from just gave you a piece of paper that says ok you own 100 goldfish. But you don’t actually have possession of them to give them away to your sister or feed them to your pet turtle, etc. on paper they are yours but those gold fish aren’t physically yours and the same goes for “buying” crypto on robinhood.

author: CalligrapherOneTwo3
body:
A lot of people are investing in Bitcoin ETFs without realizing some issues such as the fact that you will not own actual Bitcoin. Also, you will not be insured if anything happens to the ETFs. That is a pretty big risk even though this ETF can be held in a TFSA while being subjected to big swings during the weekend. Here are a few points which may or may not be helpful to you from my perspective regarding buying this alternative asset class, cold storage, taxation, and the cheapest method of accumulating/procuring it in Canada:

1. Personally, I only buy on the Newton app since they currently have the lowest purchasing fees out of all of the available exchanges in Canada. Newton's average spread varies from 0.50% to 0.60% which is 2-3 times cheaper than most of the other available exchanges that are available to us as Canadians. I also use the ShakePay app to earn free Bitcoin on a daily basis by physically shaking my phone once a day. Trust me, I know that sounds ridiculous, stupid, and suspicious, but ShakePay is a legitimate company based out of Montréal which is regulated by both FINTRAC and AMF while it is also legally licensed as a Money Service Business. I never actually buy from ShakePay because of their high purchasing spreads (which is approximately 1.75%) and I simply use them for the free daily accumulation of Bitcoin. Anyone who uses ShakePay can attest to this and easily confirm their legitimacy.
2. Since I actually want to own the underlying asset, I withdraw my Bitcoin from both of those exchanges and I put my assets into a cold storage wallet. In Canada, this is currently the cheapest method of accumulating Bitcoin and truly owning the assets by storing them "offline" in a cold storage wallet. However, in order to unlock the ShakingSats feature in ShakePay to earn free Bitcoin, you will need to be referred as per their current terms and conditions. I can assist you with that in addition to answering any general questions that you may have regarding buying, selling, converting, and taxation-related issues if you want to message me directly as I am always willing to help educate others in this space with whatever knowledge and/or experience that I have gained over the years.
3. If you want tax free capital gains, you can buy QBTC or BTCC in your TFSA. For QBTC, it is certainly expensive in terms of its historical premiums (5%-20%) and MER (1.95%); however, if you are long/bullish in Bitcoin as an alternative asset class, then perhaps it does not really matter. With that said, you do not truly own Bitcoin with QBTC or BTCC because they are a fund; and therefore, you own shares of the fund and not Bitcoin itself. As the saying goes and as you may have heard if you have done your due diligence: "not your keys, not your Bitcoin". As such, you run and operate with all of the associated risks of leaving your coins on an exchange which is why I choose to own the real thing and use a cold storage wallet. These products are not insured and same goes with the newly released ETF called BTCC. Big risk, but tax free in a TFSA.
4. You may have heard of a Canadian company named Quadriga. In short, many investors did not truly own their Bitcoin with them since Quadriga sold "entitlements to receive crypto assets or fiat currency from Quadriga" while Quadriga held the "keys" to the real Bitcoin and investors lost around 135 million dollars CAD, but up to 250 million dollars CAD according to Wikipedia. This is verifiable information, a famous story, and a perfect example of "not your keys, not your Bitcoin" as well as a lack of insurance of clients.
5. Unfortunately, with BTCC, QBTC and WealthSimple Crypto, you cannot take your Bitcoin off of their exchanges because, again, you do not truly own Bitcoin with them. Rather, you own shares of the fund whereas those organizations truly own the asset since they have the "keys". They are the ones who own the real asset (Bitcoin) and simply run the fund with the Bitcoin backing that fund as they make money through their ridiculously overpriced premiums and spread/fees (WealthSimple's spread is around 1.5-2.0% if not higher and BTCC's MER is about 1%).
6. In regards to taxes, if you truly own the asset (Bitcoin), it is subject to capital appreciation tax whenever you trigger a taxable event such as selling it, buying things with it, and/or converting crypto-to-crypto. As such, you need to be prudent in your bookkeeping behavior and calculate your "adjusted cost base" for each transaction. There is no legal requirement forcing you to calculate your "adjusted cost base" for each transaction, but it just saves you a lot of headaches later on when you need to pay taxes. This is no different than investing in traditional equities in a taxable account after you have maxed out your TFSA, RRSP, RESP, etc.
7. Before you invest in anything regardless of the asset class, make sure you understand what you are putting your money towards, understand your risk tolerance, understand the proper asset allocation percentages for your risk tolerance, and formulate a clear plan of what you want to achieve. For me, the biggest investment is not really the Bitcoin itself, but rather, it is in the underlying technology and innovation of the blockchain infrastructure which serves as a massive global public ledger leading to the decentralization of this digital currency as well as its invincibility and independence from overbearing governing bodies whereby the Bitcoin unit itself simply has a monetary value relative to fiat currency. Disclaimer: I am super long Bitcoin.

Now, here are some general points of interests to help you understand cold storage wallets:

1. There is a big misconception that if you decide to operate as your own bank (i.e.truly own your Bitcoin) and use a cold storage wallet device (i.e. physical hardware connected via USB to your PC), that your assets (Bitcoin) will be transferred and stored onto that physical USB device. This is the part that confuses a lot of people. In short, Bitcoin is not stored on that device, it will never be stored there, and this is because Bitcoin can never leave its "blockchain".
2. So, what does your cold storage device do? The device allows you to have a "key" to your asset (Bitcoin) on the blockchain. How is this "key" established? Without going too deep into the technical aspects, when you initially setup the hardware wallet device, you will be given a 24-word "seed phrase" and it is literally 24 words. From a computer science perspective, this 24-word "seed phrase" actually represents and is transcribed into a huge series/string of alphanumeric characters. This 24-word "seed phrase" is essentially your "keys" to your assets on the blockchain.
3. Your 24-word "seed phrase" is what is most important if you decide to act as your own bank and truly own Bitcoin since this is what gives you access to it. It does not matter if you lose your physical device and it does not matter if your physical device was destroyed. Why? Again, your assets are on the blockchain and not on the physical device. So, if you lose your physical device, you can simply replace it with another one (and this can be one from a different manufacturer too), set it up with your original 24-word "seed phrase" and you will once again have access to your assets since they are on the blockchain. In essence, never lose your "keys" because then you will have truly lost your Bitcoin.
4. As you can probably see now, your 24-word "seed phrase" is extremely important (and more important than the physical hardware device itself). Therefore, when you first take note of your 24-word "seed phrase" during the initial setup of your physical hardware device, make sure that no one is watching, there are no cameras around you (including your mobile phone), etc. Only you should know your "keys". Never type it out on any digital device, never e-mail it to yourself, never take a photo of it, never upload it to a cloud database such as Google Docs and never try to encrypt it and put it on a regular USB drive. You want this 24-word seed phrase as private as possible. So, if anyone/anything asks you for your "keys", never give it out. Period.

I sincerely hope that this has been helpful to you and good luck!

5. What is a blockchain? It is a transparent, public, and append-only ledger. Basically, you can add data to this transparent, open, and public ledger, but you can never edit/delete previously established data within it. This is executed by a mechanism of consensus creation between geographically scattered parties (i.e. computers) that do not need to trust each other. The parties only need to trust the consensus mechanism itself. Blockchain infrastructure relies on some form of challenge such that no single party on the network can consistently and systematically solve this challenge more than everyone else on the network. This randomizes the consensus mechanism of confirming transactions and ensures that no single party can force the blockchain ledger to accept a particular entry onto the ledger that others disagree with. This is a peer-to-peer network that can maintain updates to the ledger and verify those updates in such a way that it is impossible to defraud and impossible to alter an entry after it has been confirmed via consensus.

2. Since I actually want to own the underlying asset, I withdraw my Bitcoin from both of those exchanges and I put my assets into a cold storage wallet. In Canada, this is currently the cheapest method of accumulating Bitcoin and truly owning the assets by storing them "offline" in a cold storage wallet. However, in order to unlock the ShakingSats feature in ShakePay to earn free Bitcoin, you will need to be referred as per their current terms and conditions. I can assist you with that in addition to answering any general questions that you may have regarding buying, selling, converting, and taxation-related issues if you want to message me directly as I am always willing to help educate others in this space with whatever knowledge and/or experience that I have gained over the years.

3. If you want tax free capital gains, you can buy QBTC or BTCC in your TFSA. For QBTC, it is certainly expensive in terms of its historical premiums (5%-20%) and MER (1.95%); however, if you are long/bullish in Bitcoin as an alternative asset class, then perhaps it does not really matter. With that said, you do not truly own Bitcoin with QBTC or BTCC because they are a fund; and therefore, you own shares of the fund and not Bitcoin itself. As the saying goes and as you may have heard if you have done your due diligence: "not your keys, not your Bitcoin". As such, you run and operate with all of the associated risks of leaving your coins on an exchange which is why I choose to own the real thing and use a cold storage wallet. These products are not insured and same goes with the newly released ETF called BTCC. Big risk, but tax free in a TFSA.

4. You may have heard of a Canadian company named Quadriga. In short, many investors did not truly own their Bitcoin with them since Quadriga sold "entitlements to receive crypto assets or fiat currency from Quadriga" while Quadriga held the "keys" to the real Bitcoin and investors lost around 135 million dollars CAD, but up to 250 million dollars CAD according to Wikipedia. This is verifiable information, a famous story, and a perfect example of "not your keys, not your Bitcoin" as well as a lack of insurance of clients.

5. Unfortunately, with BTCC, QBTC and WealthSimple Crypto, you cannot take your Bitcoin off of their exchanges because, again, you do not truly own Bitcoin with them. Rather, you own shares of the fund whereas those organizations truly own the asset since they have the "keys". They are the ones who own the real asset (Bitcoin) and simply run the fund with the Bitcoin backing that fund as they make money through their ridiculously overpriced premiums and spread/fees (WealthSimple's spread is around 1.5-2.0% if not higher and BTCC's MER is about 1%).

6. In regards to taxes, if you truly own the asset (Bitcoin), it is subject to capital appreciation tax whenever you trigger a taxable event such as selling it, buying things with it, and/or converting crypto-to-crypto. As such, you need to be prudent in your bookkeeping behavior and calculate your "adjusted cost base" for each transaction. There is no legal requirement forcing you to calculate your "adjusted cost base" for each transaction, but it just saves you a lot of headaches later on when you need to pay taxes. This is no different than investing in traditional equities in a taxable account after you have maxed out your TFSA, RRSP, RESP, etc.

7. Before you invest in anything regardless of the asset class, make sure you understand what you are putting your money towards, understand your risk tolerance, understand the proper asset allocation percentages for your risk tolerance, and formulate a clear plan of what you want to achieve. For me, the biggest investment is not really the Bitcoin itself, but rather, it is in the underlying technology and innovation of the blockchain infrastructure which serves as a massive global public ledger leading to the decentralization of this digital currency as well as its invincibility and independence from overbearing governing bodies whereby the Bitcoin unit itself simply has a monetary value relative to fiat currency. Disclaimer: I am super long Bitcoin.

Now, here are some general points of interests to help you understand cold storage wallets:

1. There is a big misconception that if you decide to operate as your own bank (i.e.truly own your Bitcoin) and use a cold storage wallet device (i.e. physical hardware connected via USB to your PC), that your assets (Bitcoin) will be transferred and stored onto that physical USB device. This is the part that confuses a lot of people. In short, Bitcoin is not stored on that device, it will never be stored there, and this is because Bitcoin can never leave its "blockchain".

2. So, what does your cold storage device do? The device allows you to have a "key" to your asset (Bitcoin) on the blockchain. How is this "key" established? Without going too deep into the technical aspects, when you initially setup the hardware wallet device, you will be given a 24-word "seed phrase" and it is literally 24 words. From a computer science perspective, this 24-word "seed phrase" actually represents and is transcribed into a huge series/string of alphanumeric characters. This 24-word "seed phrase" is essentially your "keys" to your assets on the blockchain.

3. Your 24-word "seed phrase" is what is most important if you decide to act as your own bank and truly own Bitcoin since this is what gives you access to it. It does not matter if you lose your physical device and it does not matter if your physical device was destroyed. Why? Again, your assets are on the blockchain and not on the physical device. So, if you lose your physical device, you can simply replace it with another one (and this can be one from a different manufacturer too), set it up with your original 24-word "seed phrase" and you will once again have access to your assets since they are on the blockchain. In essence, never lose your "keys" because then you will have truly lost your Bitcoin. 

4. As you can probably see now, your 24-word "seed phrase" is extremely important (and more important than the physical hardware device itself). Therefore, when you first take note of your 24-word "seed phrase" during the initial setup of your physical hardware device, make sure that no one is watching, there are no cameras around you (including your mobile phone), etc. Only you should know your "keys". Never type it out on any digital device, never e-mail it to yourself, never take a photo of it, never upload it to a cloud database such as Google Docs and never try to encrypt it and put it on a regular USB drive. You want this 24-word seed phrase as private as possible. So, if anyone/anything asks you for your "keys", never give it out. Period.

5. What is a blockchain? It is a transparent, public, and append-only ledger. Basically, you can add data to this transparent, open, and public ledger, but you can never edit/delete previously established data within it. This is executed by a mechanism of consensus creation between geographically scattered parties (i.e. computers) that do not need to trust each other. The parties only need to trust the consensus mechanism itself. Blockchain infrastructure relies on some form of challenge such that no single party on the network can consistently and systematically solve this challenge more than everyone else on the network. This randomizes the consensus mechanism of confirming transactions and ensures that no single party can force the blockchain ledger to accept a particular entry onto the ledger that others disagree with. This is a peer-to-peer network that can maintain updates to the ledger and verify those updates in such a way that it is impossible to defraud and impossible to alter an entry after it has been confirmed via consensus.

I sincerely hope that this has been helpful to you and good luck!

author: Usada_Pekora
body:
Your third point is so, so silly to anyone who has a longterm view of what games retail will look like in 10-15 years. I've typed this out a few times so I'm going to give you the cliff's notes.

-PlayStation 5 has a digital-only variant with a $100 lower price tag to incentivize its purchase. 

-This $100 discount is made up easily because the only place people with that console can buy games is the PlayStation Store. 

-Sony no longer allows digital keys to be sold for its games on third party storefronts. 

-Microsoft is making moves in this space with a similar goal in mind, but a different route: XBOX Gamepass. 

-The long term strategy here is to cut out middlemen like retailers entirely so that Sony and Microsoft no longer has to give them a cut of game software sales.

-They won't complete this transition in the PS5/XSX generation, but it will almost certainly occur in the generation right after, even if it means they'll lose *some* physical media sales in the process. 

**When this finishes, Gamestop will have lost the most integral and lucrative component of its retail segment, permanently.** It doesn't matter how well they pivot, here. This is just the way the industry is moving. Sony and Microsoft want their ecosystems to be as profitable as possible. Cutting out retail reclaims a lot of built-in costs with continually decreasing downsides. At that point, Gamestop will be a retro game software, thinkgeek, funkopop, and current era *console* retailer. Fair value under $5/sh. Market is forward-looking and realizes this even if apes don't. The short stuff is the only thing propping the price up, because the company has no future.

author: TCB47
body:
Vanguard has some very good funds available in the US & I would assume they have something similar in the UK.  My wife & I have our primary investments housed with Fidelity Investment here in the U.S. and they are all in a diversified retirement account.

Current distribution is 40/60 with 40% in bond & 60% stock mutuals.  We are retirement age hence the heavier allocation to bonds.  You could get by with a heavier stock weighting.

Our stocks are split among growth funds, medical, technology and communications.  The keys for us have been to not panic and let things ride during some of the downturns.  I do rebalance the account at the first of the year to try to keep the bond/stock split close to my desired weighting.

With retirement funds, I have stayed away from straight stock ownership and for us, that has worked very well.  It's amazing what the compounding will accomplish by allowing the funds to reinvest the dividends and capital gains back info the funds.  Good luck.

BTW, I am using Robinhood to "play" with options with some disposable, not going to miss it, funds.  I just won't get wild with the retirement account.

author: dont-YOLO-ragequit
body:
This really lack any due Diligence. 
Are you just trolling to get the answers fed to you or did you just poorly formulated a Change my view post? 

Doesn't reay matter who invented it as the basis of it has been optimized by the competition between all crypto currencies. In other words the un verified unsecured currencies died a decade plus ago from not being hack proof.

The currencies are currently competing with each other the same way the Yen, Euro, US dollar and more are competing with each other. They all have their own supply and demand and the more credible companies hop on, the more credible it will get.(compared to currencies being manipulated by stimulus packages, interest rates and buying other currencies). 


It IS being regulated and audited. The mid February crash happened because some firm falsely stated that they found a double transaction. It was later backtracked but the damage was done. 

The values is linked to how hard it is to mine 1 coin at this point. You could mine a coin with an idle computer so at the time it was chump change, now it takes high powered hardware, a heavy electricity bill and a ton of cooling to get one so the price goes along with it + how it can only get harder to have one. 

Your coins are as secure as you make it. There are crypted USB keys  to keep your wallet safe but like everything, the more valuable it is, the more someone will have the patience to get it.

The future is in that it cuts currency exchange fees(the banks) and rates(the government) and financial institutions from host to client. You get a coin, you trade parts of it the way you want internationally or confidentially with no brick and mortar fees. 

The GME saga showed big banks can and will interfere to make money over the well being of free market.

Bitcoin might not be the end all solution but something can be said about the infrastructure behind it where no "package"(hash) can be hacked since the time and date , the number of characters, sender and receivers , and so much of the the data that makes the hash can be used to encrypt it thus can't be "reinserted" in the blockchain.

author: ScarletHark
body:
A comment I was replying to was deleted, it was basically asking about different ways to play semis this summer on a budget, and mentioned they had done calls on SOXL and puts on SOXS so far. So I wanted to post the reply here anyway.

\---------------------------------------------------------------------------

SOXL/counter-SOXS is a good way to play the semi expansion through all of its phases; I have long SOXL in my investment account for this reason. It's 3x levered already, so adding leverage through options takes nerves of steel, because that leverage swings both directions -- you will need to ride out the stomach-churning drops that can happen day-to-day. However, swing-trading or scalping options on SOXL/SOXS can work, because the semi industry only has tailwinds right now, and at 1,000 feet, I think SOX/SOXL/counter-SOXS trends upwards through this year.

It's possible to do the same with individual names, including some of the ones I mentioned. One of the issues will be figuring out whether the recent gap-ups in names like AMAT, ASML, LRCX and TER are fully pricing in PEG, because AMAT jumped from 24x TTM earnings to 30x; TER jumped from about the same level to 27x; LRCX to 28x. But that's all TTM earnings -- these companies are expecting additional earnings growth this year on the back of announcements by Intel and TSMC to spend upwards of at least $120B over the next three years ($100B announced by TSMC, $20B so far announced by Intel, with a hint of more to come later this year). In Feb 2021, [the AMAT earnings release had already painted a rosy picture for 2021](https://www.fool.com/earnings/call-transcripts/2021/02/19/applied-materials-amat-q1-2021-earnings-call-trans/); we'll possibly know more come the [AMAT Investor Day on April 6](https://ir.appliedmaterials.com/events/event-details/investor-meeting). Also know that AMAT supplies not just the CPU/GPU manufacturers, but also has good exposure to the memory semiconductor manufacturers, such as Micron (MU), who just had an incredible ER and gave impressive 2021 projections.

I keep singling out AMAT because in terms of options, they are the most liquid, and therefore the most accessible; ASML and LRCX are great companies but their options chains tend to be less liquid than AMAT's; LRCX is a bit better than ASML's in this regard. These could be good LEAPS opportunities if you are willing to wait out IV before entering, and wait out buyers when you go to sell. TER only has monthlies, and have OK liquidity around the money, but you can still get decent action out to 0.04 delta above the money on TER calls. TER IVR is currently 11, but the options are still running in the 40s/50s for IV. 

I had previously done 113/114 put credit spreads on AMAT for Mar-5 and Mar-12 expirations, and those both held (Mar-5 closed at 113.45 IIRC, however). I later opened a PMCC on AMAT for Jan22\[80c\]/Mar-26\[121c\] and ended up chasing the short higher because AMAT jumped so fast (up to that point, AMAT had been trending steadily upwards, but not leaping like it has the past few days). I was able to get out of the short (which I had rolled to Apr-9 125) when AMAT retreated a bit, and then sold the LEAPS too because I figured the spike was done -- regretting that now. ;) I'm waiting a few more days to see if the churn is done (and for IV to come back down), and will probably open another LEAPS on it at some point. AMAT is still pretty volatile -- IVR 46 (which is unusual for them up to this point this year) and Apr-16 options are still in the 40s and 50s, favoring selling, rather than paying, premiums. 

I don't think we see a retreat in any of these names this summer; they've been able to withstand the rotation in and out of tech the past couple of weeks, which suggests that traders and investors are finally done painting everything that smells of tech with the same broad brush.

author: ScarletHark
body:
I work in the semi industry and I've been in and out of AMAT positions the past couple of months. TSM, Samsung and INTC have near-term headwinds in terms of earnings based on semiconductor demand simply because it takes so long to expand capacity. The front-end winners in current semi production efforts are going to be those who supply the tools, products and services that go into these fabs that are planned for construction: AMAT, ASML, TER, LRCX, to name a few. Secondary effects on earnings from this will come 1-2-3 years down the line for the semi manufacturers themselves, depending on whether or not they are expanding/upgrading an existing facility, or building one from the ground up.

The end-users of these semiconductor products (GM, F, NVDA, AMD, etc.) will be the last ones to benefit from expanded chipmaking capacity, as easing the demand crunch allows them to resume normal sales levels. Note that for auto mfrs, this has a ripple effect on rental car companies, who sold all of their fleets in fire sales last year and now can't replace them because the auto mfrs can't make cars.

Additionally, TSMC is booked up for the foreseeable future; these bookings have prices agreed well in advance, and are almost certainly not subject to TSMC's recent statements that they plan to increase prices; that will happen with new bookings down the line.

author: ThisPomelo4
body:
Your analysis is probably true for delta, but the problem with playing those names using vol is that the IV is higher. Options trading is most useful when you get the gamma cheap while also calling the direction right.

I'm buying INTC 23Apr 70c because resistance at 65 has kept IV muted. My bet is that INTC will break through that resistance on 6Apr or 23Apr. I hate talking in terms of resistance in general, but looking at the long-term chart as well as price action in the morning after the Intel Unleashed event, it certainly seems like you'd need a big catalyst to justify a breakout beyond 65. I'd probably play those profits -- if any -- into AMD puts through to May, because I think hedge fund selling will take place when Lisa Su inevitably acknowledges the incorrectness of her prediction that supply "tightness" would clear up by 2H21.

I also believe that the Archegos liquidation is another sign that correlated hedge fund losses will spell disaster for the market. We saw this already with GME and the other short-squeeze names. Chipmakers like to lay out their capex as close to production ramp-up as possible, which means that LRCX/AMAT/ASML/KLIC/KLAC/CAJ/etc won't book profits immediately even if billions of dollars are allocated to the roadmap. So I'm waiting for a big selloff this summer to get into those names as a long-term position. May try to play that selloff using hedgie favorites and names that have a lot of room to fall. ARKK, TSLA, TSM, NVDA come to mind. TSM seems counterintuitive but you get the added potential catalyst of Chinese brinkmanship as well as a deepening of the water supply woes.

I mention CAJ because it gives a good read on DUV demand. Their equipment segment had a lot of profit growth last quarter. But it's not as good a play as the others because only a fifth of its revenue comes from that segment.

author: Craino
body:
TL:DR - looking for feedback on a simple hi return stock screen and thoughts on how to rank results.

Early 60's, simple, diversified, buy and hold retirement portfolio approach my whole life. Looking at working probably another 5-10 years and starting to get a lot more active in my portfolio. Nothing crazy and I'm fundamentally a conservative+ investor, but I do not subscribe to moving 100% into ultra safe right before retirement. Portfolio size is low 7 figure for reference.

Over the past few months I subscribed to a couple of authors on Seeking Alpha and have tried out a few strategies with minimal exposure and have a good idea of how to use some of the approaches in my portfolio. I want to develop my own screens because at least on Seeking Alpha, the authors I've found charge a small monthly fee for their updates. It's nothing huge, and for me at least has been worth seeing their approaches, but nothing I want to pay for the rest of my life.

I'm going to put together a dividend screen/strategy and a "better than cash" parking lot strategy. Pretty basic and straightforward. I also just got started on putting together a screen to identify a more hi growth strategy - thought being on a monthly basis invest in the top 4 stocks that fall out of the screen. Would love some feedback on the screen (I'm stock knowledgeable, but certainly not an expert). When looking at the screen and giving feedback keep in mind my objective: not looking for the perfect approach or for mega returns, I'm an 80/20 kinda guy so looking for a decent, simple to execute strategy to reliably give back a growth-class return. (And using the Fidelity screener as that's where my portfolio is).

Screen as it stand currently:

* Tagging Energy, Health Care, Financials, Information Technology and Industrials sectors
* Market cap down to Medium (as defined by Fidelity: 6-33B)
* 13 week price performance down to 13%
* 3 yr annualized Beta of 1.1 and up (conflicted on whether this really helps the screen)
* Very Bullish or Bullish analyst recommendations (Summary score from StarMine)
* Forward EPS 3-5 yrs high to very high (16.5% and up)
* EPS growth Projected year versus last year high to very high (40% and up)

As an example, running that screen today resulted in a list of 7 stocks (sorry not allowed to link image or would give you a shot of the fundamentals):

1. AMAT - Applied materials
2. FANG - Diamondback Energy
3. EOG - EOG Resources
4. NXPI - NXP SemiConductor
5. KKR - KKR & Co
6. LRCX - LAM Research Corp
7. MU - Micron Technology

So the thought would be to run this first day of every month and put a set amount in the top 4 stocks in the filter. I would guess some stocks might stay in for months, some might rotate in and out quickly.

My question is basically around how to rank. So do I just pick a screening metric (or some other metric) and do a simple rank on that metric to determine top 4, or do I create a formula to weight and aggregate multiple metrics into an overall score and rank on that?

Sorry for the long post - thank you to those who stuck with it and are willing to share your thoughts.

body:
I work in the semi industry and I've been in and out of AMAT positions the past couple of months. TSM, Samsung and INTC have near-term headwinds in terms of earnings based on semiconductor demand simply because it takes so long to expand capacity. The front-end winners in current semi production efforts are going to be those who supply the tools, products and services that go into these fabs that are planned for construction: AMAT, ASML, TER, LRCX, to name a few. Secondary effects on earnings from this will come 1-2-3 years down the line for the semi manufacturers themselves, depending on whether or not they are expanding/upgrading an existing facility, or building one from the ground up.

The end-users of these semiconductor products (GM, F, NVDA, AMD, etc.) will be the last ones to benefit from expanded chipmaking capacity, as easing the demand crunch allows them to resume normal sales levels. Note that for auto mfrs, this has a ripple effect on rental car companies, who sold all of their fleets in fire sales last year and now can't replace them because the auto mfrs can't make cars.

Additionally, TSMC is booked up for the foreseeable future; these bookings have prices agreed well in advance, and are almost certainly not subject to TSMC's recent statements that they plan to increase prices; that will happen with new bookings down the line.

author: ThisPomelo4
body:
Your analysis is probably true for delta, but the problem with playing those names using vol is that the IV is higher. Options trading is most useful when you get the gamma cheap while also calling the direction right.

I'm buying INTC 23Apr 70c because resistance at 65 has kept IV muted. My bet is that INTC will break through that resistance on 6Apr or 23Apr. I hate talking in terms of resistance in general, but looking at the long-term chart as well as price action in the morning after the Intel Unleashed event, it certainly seems like you'd need a big catalyst to justify a breakout beyond 65. I'd probably play those profits -- if any -- into AMD puts through to May, because I think hedge fund selling will take place when Lisa Su inevitably acknowledges the incorrectness of her prediction that supply "tightness" would clear up by 2H21.

I also believe that the Archegos liquidation is another sign that correlated hedge fund losses will spell disaster for the market. We saw this already with GME and the other short-squeeze names. Chipmakers like to lay out their capex as close to production ramp-up as possible, which means that LRCX/AMAT/ASML/KLIC/KLAC/CAJ/etc won't book profits immediately even if billions of dollars are allocated to the roadmap. So I'm waiting for a big selloff this summer to get into those names as a long-term position. May try to play that selloff using hedgie favorites and names that have a lot of room to fall. ARKK, TSLA, TSM, NVDA come to mind. TSM seems counterintuitive but you get the added potential catalyst of Chinese brinkmanship as well as a deepening of the water supply woes.

I mention CAJ because it gives a good read on DUV demand. Their equipment segment had a lot of profit growth last quarter. But it's not as good a play as the others because only a fifth of its revenue comes from that segment.
